text: Family Member: Mm. Doctor: But the, yeah, so the, I can print this out for you too, just so that you have it for your records. The testing to see if you have the hereditary risk of cancer was negative. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Alright, so of these options, what I think is reasonable, and what I think is not reasonable. Observation for you actually, I don't think is reasonable. You're a pretty healthy guy. You're a pretty healthy guy. And you don't have any comorbidities. You know, I would expect you to live if you didn't have prostate cancer, I would expect to live for at least another 10 years. So I think that we should do something more than observation, right? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. So this one would not be my first choice. Intermittent hormone therapy, I think if you wanted to go for a standard approach, like what everybody else is doing, I think that that is a very reasonable option. The downside is that you would be exposed to hormone therapy. And when we get to, if you ever get to this phase where you have metastatic disease where we can see your lymph nodes or see disease in the bones, you get started on hormonal hormone therapy anyways. So what usually happens in this approach is that you're getting it every six months. And, you know, maybe you get it for six months and you’re off of it for two years, maybe three years together for six months or a year, go for six months necessarily. This is certainly not a bad option. This is the standard option. This is what we consider the standard of care, like what's most widely accepted. And this could be an option now or later. You know, having talked to you before. I think what we should maybe try and do first is see if you'd be eligible and if you have this genotype for the MAP study. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: You mentioned before that you were taking a number of supplements and you know, we're interested in natural products and how they may help your risk of cancer or cancer progression. Doctor: So, I think that that would be a reasonable first approach to see and hear. You know, first to see if you're eligible for the study- Patient: Okay. Doctor: -and then, get the genetic testing for the study. And then if you are, join that study. Patient: Okay.

text: Patient: Oh it’s every three weeks. Doctor: Correct. Patient: So I would take two or three treatments? Doctor: Uh, I’m thinking right now three, three, then we do a repeat scan. And if it’s working, if things are shrinking in there, we keep going. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: On an average people get six. The typical sort of maximum if people are having a tremendous benefit and doing fine with it, you know I can go up to ten. But, but we’ll see how it goes. Patient: Well, I mean (chuckles) Doctor: No, no, I think the hair loss is all pretty much even after one or two, so after we stop the hair grows back. Family Member: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: So, so, that does happen. The other thing to watch for is if there’s tingling or numbness, okay, typically in the fingertips and the toes. If that is happening, I will, you know we may have to make adjustments to the dose. What happens is we start everyone on one standard dose and then dial down, depending on how they’re tolerated. Okay, so, so I think like I told you, the first course pretty much is important because both you and I will find out how you’re going to tolerate. Patient: Right, well my my feet, you know even like right now, they’re a little tingly. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: But I - you know from sitting in the car for an hour coming up here and that’s -

text: Patient: Yes. Doctor: Which we think is probably prostate cancer. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And uh we had discussed a lot of options around that that we were gonna talk a little bit more about today is this concept of giving a special type of radiation therapy which called stereotactic radiotherapy to that lymph node. Possibly to other lymph nodes as well. This is a very focused beam of ray therapy that also goes by many other names included the name CyberKnife even though it’s not a true knife. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: But uh it’s kind of precise as a knife which is where it got the name. It’s also called SBRT, stereotactic body radiotherapy. With SBRT or Cyber Knife or stereotactic radiotherapy it’s always the same thing. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? So we have um two or three uh radiation oncologists here that specialize in that type of therapy for prostate cancer patients. And the other things that are I want to discuss um with you today is a clinical trial – Patient: Okay. Doctor: - where we’re using that type of therapy but instead of not using it and not following um patients and getting data from them, we want learn something from their experience. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: And also want to compare the outcomes of patients who get the stereotactic radiotherapy immediately versus those that are observed for a period of time and then we’ll get the stereotactic radiotherapy a little bit later. PAT; Okay. Patient: Okay.

text: Healthcare Professional: Thirty days, I do believe. From the, um, the, the Doctor: From the hormone first Healthcare Professional: hormone first. text: Patient: Uh, and then look at the other options. So, is that, is the one that is phase one is that, that window like a real tight window. That seven days from now, it’s gonna be closed? Doctor: Umm. I don’t know that. So, when I spoke to Dr. P_, all she let me know was that there was a slot. You know, that would be something that we would say once you’ve decided or that we’ve given you the consent form that we have a potential patient who’s interested, that they would save that slot for you. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because they would, I assume, that there is going to need to be a twenty-eight day washout of your current therapy. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then, maybe that you have to repeat scans prior to that. Um, the adrenal glands. The, the big wild card there right now what I can clearly state that it is not specific. I don’t know what it is. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And again, that’s the radiologists can’t agree on what it is. Patient: So, would I have to have something done to go into the adrenal glands or, uh, the, the tests that confirm that whether it is cancer or not cancer? Doctor: Um, no. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. And then if you decided to go with chemotherapy, it would be just one of the many spots that we would watch for change in response to.

text: Family Member: If he thinks he has a hernia, would that show on the CT scan? Would that be appropriate to send to the doctor? Doctor: No, because, yeah, the hernia, you know, when you’re laying down it really has to be pretty bad for it to be seen laying down. It’s usually when you’re standing up or sitting that it comes out. A hernia just means you have a weak area of muscle and then you have your bowel spill out. Typically, it doesn’t bother you unless it gets stuck, you know. Patient: Okay. Family Member: He’s having a lot of pain shooting up. Patient: Just I have a problem with my groin Doctor: Yeah. Patient: because that’s another problem I’m having to get my doctor to maybe get that taken, Doctor: Yeah. Patient: but it don’t hurt walking Doctor: No. Patient: or doing anything so. Doctor: Yeah, so you’ve seen a surgeon specifically for the hernia?

text: Patient: -- of this is what the scan report is gonna read which I’m gonna give you right now. So this – but the same areas were the lower back and the left hip, the hip bones, so those are the two main areas. Family Member: And the rib or not the rib? Doctor: The ribs are still there and we are following it. It’s in the left side on the sixth rib. Yeah I mean that also was there before Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: and that stayed about the same. Family Member: But the increased uptake is in the lower back and the left hip? Patient: Previously we were under the impression that the scans were the good news that they haven’t changed. Doctor: I think that is still true. Okay, so my assessment of these scans are they are stable. Okay. Patient: Uh but the PSA which had been going down turned around last month to point four from one point one but then now it’s at one point four doesn’t sound good. Doctor: No. So obviously… Patient: So am I going off the Xtandi or what? Doctor: Well so we have a few choices okay. One is do we add another medication, because typically people who are sort of resistant to Xtandi. There are a couple of pathways of resistance that we know about now. Okay. One of which is something we called BET1 overexpression. B-E-T okay and you’ll get paperwork on this but. So that pathway there is a BET1 inhibitor that we are testing right now.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
